Package org.jspecify.meta

Annotation Interface Implies

@Documented @Retention(RUNTIME) @Target(ANNOTATION_TYPE) public @interface Implies
Indicates that an annotation type conveys all of the same meaning as the given annotation type(s); for example, @Implies(One.class) @interface Two {} says that any usage of @Two implicitly conveys all the same meaning as @One (with no attributes) would in the same location. Note that the Two annotation type may add additional meaning of its own as well, and may be applicable in locations where One is not.

We will refer to this example throughout this documentation: 


 public @interface One {}

 // Additional meaning of `@Two`, if any, specified here.
 @Implies(One.class)
 public @interface Two {}

 // These might be classes, fields, methods, etc.
 @One declaration_a
 @Two declaration_b
 @One @Two declaration_c

In this example, the meaning conveyed by the annotations is exactly the same for declaration_b and declaration_c; there, @One is considered redundant (but harmless). A JSpecify-compatible tool will treat the two identically (apart from optionally reporting the redundancy itself).

Warning: These annotations are under development, and any aspect of their naming, locations, or design is subject to change until the JSpecify 1.0 release. Moreover, supporting analysis tools will be tracking the changes on varying schedules. Releasing a library using these annotations in its API is strongly discouraged at this time.

Details

An array of other annotation types may be provided, indicating that this annotation type (the one that is itself annotated with @Implies) carries (at least) the combined meanings of all of them.

In the example above, if Two does not define any additional semantics, and lists only one implied annotation, we call it an alias for One. In this case, the annotations on all three example declarations above convey identical meaning, and should be treated identically by tools.

Implication is naturally transitive: if in addition to the example code above we also have @Implies(Two.class) @interface Three {}, it is understood that Three also implies One. Listing One.class explicitly is redundant but harmless.

It is not possible to supply custom attribute values for an implied annotation, such as declaring that @Two implies @One("arg") or that @Two(key = VALUE) implies @One(key = VALUE).

The target types of One and Two may differ. @Two may therefore appear in a location where @One cannot; for these usages @Implies has no effect. The target types of One and Two might even be disjoint. For example if they are {FIELD} and {TYPE_USE}, there are still source locations where either can appear (before the type of a field), so the implication still has meaning.

If Two has wider retention than One, then in any situation where @One would not be visible, the effect of @Implies is undefined.

  • Required Element Summary

    Required Elements
    Modifier and Type
    Required Element
    Description
    Class<? extends Annotation>[]
    value
    The annotation types implied by this annotation type (the one that is itself annotated with Implies).

  • Element Details

    • value

      Class<? extends Annotation>[] value
      The annotation types implied by this annotation type (the one that is itself annotated with Implies). May not include any annotation type that declares an attribute with no default value. Listing this annotation type itself in the array, or any annotation type that is already transitively implied by another listed, is redundant but harmless. (A larger cycle of implication is acceptable.) Any number of types can be given. Their order is irrelevant. A duplicate type in the array is redundant but harmless. If the array is empty (e.g., @Implies({}) @interface One), this entire annotation is redundant but harmless.
      Returns:
      the annotation types implied by this annotation type
